descript.abstract: Southeast Aquatic Connectivity Assessment Project (SEACAP) Database of Dams is a compilation of dams within the HUC 4 watersheds draining into the South Atlantic Landscape Conservation Cooparative boundary. This boundary includes parts of VA, NC, SC, GA, AL, FL, and part of MS. It is intented to be the input dataset for the SEACAP Tool, which prioritizes dams for removal or fish passage based on suite of ecologically-relevant metrics which assess the potential ecological benefit of conducting a removal or other passage project.
descript.purpose: The Southeast Aquatic Connectivity Assessment Project (SEACAP) Database of Dams is intented to be the input dataset for the SEACAP Tool, which prioritizes dams for removal or fish passage based on ecological benefit.

timeperd.current: within the HUC 4 watersheds draining into the South Atlantic Landscape Conservation Cooparative boundary. This boundary includes parts of VA, NC, SC, GA, AL, FL, and part of MS.

idinfo.accconst: The Nature Conservancy and SARP shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. Any sale, in whole or in part, is prohibited without the approval of the Nature Conservancy and SARP. The use of these data to produce other GIS products and services with the intent to sell for a profit is prohibited without the written consent of the Nature Conservancy and SARP. All parties receiving these data must be informed of these restrictions. The Nature Conservancy and SARP shall be acknowledged as data contributors to any reports or other products derived from these data.
idinfo.useconst: The Nature Conservancy and SARP reserves all rights to the TNC/SARP data provided. All data are provided as is. The information provided is not a survey quality dataset. The Nature Conservancy and SARP make no warranty as to the currency, completeness, accuracy or utility of any specific data. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data.
idinfo.datacred: The Nature Conservancy, The Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership

srcinfo.srccontr: National Anthropogenic Barrier Dataset (NABD) This dataset is a spatially accurate dataset where NID 2009 dams were snapped to the medium resolution of NHD plus version 1.

citeinfo.title: NHD Dam Events
citeinfo.othercit: These data were created by the US EPA and the US Geological Survey

srcinfo.srccontr: NHD dam events from 2013. These are dam points on the high resolution NHD plus river network.

citeinfo.title: National Inventory of Dams
citeinfo.othercit: These data were downloaded for inclusion in SEACAP in May of 2013. for more information contact: nid@usace.army.mil.

srcinfo.srccontr: National Inventory of Dams, 2013. This dataset is created and updated by the US Army Corps of Engineers and includes dams 25 feet and higher in the nation.

citeinfo.title: EPA Dams, Georgia
citeinfo.othercit: These data were obtained by Duncan Elkins from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Office of Water OST. Published in 1998.

srcinfo.srccontr: Georgia dams from the US Environmental Protection Agency, 4435 dams compiled in a database by Duncan Elkins and Nate Nibbelink (UGA) as part of a Compilation of field and GIS-based barrier assessment studies in the Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership (SARP) region.

citeinfo.title: Tallapoosa Impoundments
citeinfo.othercit: Obtained by Duncan Elkins from Elise Erwin, Auburn. Created in July of 2004.

srcinfo.srccontr: Tallapoosa Impoundments. 5967 small dams within the Tallapoosa watershed, which spans parts of Georgia and Alabama. Compiled in a database by Duncan Elkins and Nate Nibbelink (UGA) as part of a Compilation of field and GIS-based barrier assessment studies in the Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership (SARP) region,

Florida EPA dams. 590 dams compiled in a database by Duncan Elkins and Nate Nibbelink (UGA) as part of a Compilation of field and GIS-based barrier assessment studies in the Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership (SARP) region, 1996.

citeinfo.title: Florida Suannee Water Management District Dams
citeinfo.othercit: Leroy Marshall II, P.E., CFM Senior Professional Engineer Suwannee River Water Management District

srcinfo.srccitea: Florida Suannee Water Management District Dams
srcinfo.srccontr: Dams from Florida Water Management District, Suwannee region. Received from Leroy Marshall II, P.E., CFM Senior Professional Engineer, Suwannee River Water Management District

srcinfo.srccontr: Small dams from several counties in Alabama, provided by Wardell Edwards, M.P.A., ADECA - Office of Water Resources. Counties: Alabama Shelby County Alabama Tuscaloosa County Alabama Jefferson County Alabama St. Clair County Alabama Blount County Alabama Marshall County Alabama Etowah County
Alabama Mill Dams, from the following scientific paper: Helms, et al. The influence of low head dams on fish assemblages in streams across Alabama. J. N. Am. Benthol. Soc., 2011, 30(4):1095–1106.

citeinfo.title: VA Dam Safety Database
citeinfo.othercit:

Richmond, VA 23219

srcinfo.srccontr: Virginia Dam Safety Database. Obtained from Robert T. Bennett, PE, RA, CFM, Division Director, Division of Dam Safety & Floodplain Management and Jing Li.

North Carolina Fish Barrier Inventory, created by Kat Hoenke (SARP) for the North Carolina Barrier Prioritization Tool. Consists of dams from the North Carolina Dam Safety Database (2013), Aquatic Obstruction Inventory (NCDENR/USFWS, 2008), NC/VA Coastal Barriers (NC DMF), field observations from American Rivers.
USFWS Geospatial Fisheries Information Network (GEOFIN) inventory, mostly used for reference. GEOFIN_ID incorporated into this database to link back.
South Carolina Dam Safety Database. Obtained in 2011.

09-432 Alabama and Florida Impoundments. Small dams in parts of NC and FL. Obtained from Kathy Freeman. Published in Nov 2011, in the following report: Herrington, Steven J. 2011. Inventory and Prioritization of Impaired Sites in the Yellow River Watershed in Alabama and Florida. Department of Defense Legacy Program.

Estimated Dams, modeled by Analie Barnett, TNC.These dams were estimated using the NHDplus version 2 medium resloution hydrography network and waterbodies. Where a water body polygon intersected the river network, a dam point was created. Estimated dams overlapping with known database dams were removed, and then the rest of the dams were manually analyzed using a coding system, to eliminate swamps and errors.

procstep.procdesc: 2) Retained any NHD dam events or NID 2013 dams that did not overlap with NABD as new individual dams.
3) Possible duplicates coded as NABD or NHD dam event dikes removed
4) NID 2013, NABD, NID 2006, and 2005 were used to fill in any missing attributes using NIDID as join ID.
5) Find national dupliates within the same dataset, 100m from one another, as well national dams within 500m of one another having similar names.

State dams with a common NID or state ID in a national dataset were coded as duplicates, and state dams that were within 100m (or a greater distance, if visual inspection showed more duplicates) of national dams were also coded as duplicates.

1) Maintained all snapping of NABD (NID 2009). Used a join function to identify all NID 2013 dams with identical NIDIDs. Retained all NID 2013 attributes for NIDID dams if these attributes were available. Maintained all snapping of NHD dam events and retained any NID 2013 attributes.
- Pre- Snap all dams on NABD and NHD dam events with matching reachcodes (Y in snapto100k field). Snap all dams within 100m to flowline, assuming they are in the correct location.
Prioritizing dams for snapping review, using criteria like small dam on large river, etc. Dams on large size class rivers prioritized first.
All dams within 100m of the NHD plus medium resolution were snapped to the river.

attr.attrdefs: Database where the dam is found.

attr.attrdef: Status of the dam BREACHED DRAINED EXEMPT IMPOUNDING
Dam owner type F - Federal S - State L - Local Government U - Utility P - Private
Dam Type RE (for EARTH) ER (for ROCKFILL) PG (for GRAVITY) CB (for BUTTRESS) VA (for ARCH) MV (for MULTI-ARCH) CN (for CONCRETE) MS (for MASONRY) ST (for STONE) TC (for TIMBER CRIB) OT (for OTHER)

Dam Purpose I (for IRRIGATION) H (for HYDROELECTRIC) C (for FLOOD CONTROL OR STORMWATER MANAGEMENT) N (for NAVIGATIONAL LOCKS) S (for WATER SUPPLY) R (for RECREATION) P (for FIRE PROTECTION, STOCK POND OR SMALL FARM POND) F (for FISH and WILDLIFE POND) D (for DEBRIS or SEDIMENT CONTROL) T (for TAILINGS) O (for OTHER, such as waste or treatment lagoons)
Year the dam was built
Height of the dam in feet
Width of the dam in feet
Length of the dam in feet
Basin where the dam is located
Surface area of the impoundment at normal pool in acres to the nearest tenth of an acre, or to the nearest acre.
Drainage area of the dam in acres to the nearest acre.
The capacity of all spillways up to the crest of the dam (i.e., to the top of the dam) in cfs (cubic feet per second) to the nearest cfs.
Maximum storage, in acre-feet, which is defined as the total storage space in a reservoir below the maximum attainable water surface elevation, including any surcharge storage.

Normal storage, in acre-feet, which is defined as the total storage space in a reservoir below the normal retention level, including dead and inactive storage and excluding any flood control or surcharge storage.
A calculated field based on the maximum value of field items #30 Maximum Storage and #31 Normal storage, providing a single storage value to facilitate database queries.
Removal status Planned Removed
Dam impoundment is a lake, has the word "LAKE" in its name Y N
Latitude, in decimal degrees
Longitude, in decimal degrees
Longitude of the snapped dam
Latitude of snapped dam
River Size Class
SEACAP Workgroup-defined resident fish subregion
Dam Condition
Comments from manual snapping in the NABD analysis
Commnts from field observers in NC
Comments on the condition of the dam.
Type of data source (e.g. federal, state)
Source of the record
FERC License Expiration
Fish Passage at the dam Y N
